title: Carter radio interview
content: Did anyone else hear Matthew Carter on NPR's [_On the Media_](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123149/http:/www.wnyc.org/onthemedia/) this week? He's such a gentleman -- even laughed obligingly when the interviewer said he was "a font of knowledge," yuk yuk yuk. (The story was about the NYT headline overhaul with Cheltenham.)
author: meredith

comments.content: I remember Matthew's amusement at being introduced at the HOW conference a few years ago as 'a living icon'. He thought it made him sound like an animated bitmap in the corner of one's desktop.

I was just getting ready to post to see if anyone could summarize it when I saw this thread. I turned on NPR and it's Matthew Carter, though I only heard the end of the interview. What a nice surprise it was.   
But I'm even more surprised after reading the first few paragraphs of the interview. I just used Cheltenham as a headline font on a recent (and very small) project about fire trucks. (And I'm not even close to being a font of knowledge)   
I've really been interested lately in slab serifs, it started when I read this short article by Robin Williams awhile back:   
   
 [http://www.eyewire.com/magazine/columns/robin/slabserifs/index.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123149/http:/www.eyewire.com/magazine/columns/robin/slabserifs/index.htm)   
  
My other favorite slab at the moment is Chaparral MM. Anyhow, going to read the rest of the interview, thanks for the On the Media link!

ha, this is funny..   
   
"Like the drought-resistant brush that blooms on the arid coastal range near Twombly�s California home, Chaparral�s highly functional design is surprisingly beautiful."   
�adobe.com/type/
I loved that interview I caught it last Sunday. He's very witty.

He is witty, but I don't think OTM did a very good job interviewing him (despite that it's one of my favorite NPR programs). I thought the earlier interview -- the one where the interviewer tried to give him credit for Helvetica -- was better.

Meredith, just for the record, Matthew did design Helvetica Compressed, Extra Compressed, and Ultra Compressed in 1966 for Linotype filmsetting. I didn't hear that interview, so I don't know if those might be what the interviewer was crediting him for.   
   
-- K.

Meredith, that interview wasn't aimed at anyone who has a clue about type or type design. It was a piece of fluff. So I take it for what it is, fun and lighthearted. I bet most people who read the Times didn't notice the difference. Dan
